title: Victoria goes it alone in stepping out and up in Asia
text:
“It is very activist and more ambitious in some ways than Canberra,” he says.

Warwick Smith, inaugural chair of the federal government’s National Foundation for Australia China Relations, also praises the Asian focus of the Victorian government, saying NSW has fallen behind in this area in recent years.

Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews. AAP

Not that this has stopped Smith from setting up the new headquarters of the federal government’s new foundation in Sydney.

But the opening of the Asia Society’s Melbourne office is an example of the state’s attempt to play a greater role in promoting the need for Victorian businesses to look offshore for growth as well as encourage investment and ties.

In the public service, this push has been strongly supported by Chris Eccles, head of the department of Premier and Cabinet in Victoria, who used to hold the same position in NSW.

Asia Society board member Andrew Michelmore – Melbourne-based and business veteran in dealing with a range of Asian economies – says the organisation’s expansion is logical given Victoria’s cultural strengths as well as its multicultural history.

“It’s important to understand the culture of Asian countries in order to develop the relationships and the trust,” he says. “That takes time.”

Advertisement

The establishment of the office coincides with a new taskforce set up by the Asia Society and the Business Council of Australia to examine how companies can increase and diversify their presence in Asia. The plan is to present recommendations to governments within 12 months.

The taskforce is chaired by Mark van Dyck, head of Compass Group Asia Pacific, a food services company with $3.5 billion annual sales in Asia and nearly 70,000 employees.

“The job of the taskforce will be to look at practical ways for Australian companies to build sustainable and successful businesses in Asia,” he says. “We want to focus on specifically how we can do that, for instance by identifying successful business models and what leadership skills are necessary to deliver results.”

Political leadership also remains a work in progress, especially when it comes to China.

Warwick Smith, who is a former chair of the Asia Society among other roles, describes himself as an optimist who believes there will be a US-China trade deal. He also predicts Scott Morrison will be invited to visit Beijing sometime in the new year and that there is considerable diplomatic effort underway to facilitate this.

Such an outcome still seems remote right now – even with the determined efforts of the Morrison government to downplay the level of tension between Australia and its biggest trading partner.

Morrison continues to focus publicly on the value of Australia’s comprehensive strategic partnership with China and the great benefits of China’s economic success – staking out a different position to the US on this despite mutual criticism of China’s manipulation of trading rules.

The Prime Minister also insists he is not "vexed” by the lack of an invitation to visit Beijing, part of the diplomatic deep freeze with Beijing that has stymied high-level ministerial visits for two years.

Advertisement

But Philipp Ivanov is one of many experts describing the Australia China relationship as in the worst shape it has been for 30 years, since the Tiananmen Square massacre. He speaks from considerable experience as he was in charge of the China desk at the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade before Smith persuaded him to head up the Asia Society.

“It’s obviously a very different environment now,” he says. “I don’t want to say it’s caused by clumsy statements or decisions by the Australian government. A lot of the current freeze and tensions have been caused by the actions of China itself and the responses to that.

“China now is more global, more assertive, more powerful economically and more authoritarian. But we do need to find a way to engage with China. Whether we agree or disagree with its foreign policy trajectory or its economic policy trajectory, we have to better understand the thinking to know how best to deal with this.”

Ivanov, who was born in Vladivostok, says the current situation with China is nothing like dealing with Russia, which had a weak economy and was an insignificant part of the global economy.

“China is one face of the global economy and the US is the other face and we as a middle power need to find a way to engage with both, but it won’t be easy.”

Just ask Scott Morrison.
description: Canberra's criticism of Victoria for signing up to China's Belt and Road Initiative has not stopped Daniel Andrews’ focus on establishing greater engagement with Asia.
